The Gunboat Mk.II, code named (Narwhal), is a bigger, badder, and improved version of the previous gunboat design.  The biggest difference is the addition of a deeper hull which significantly improves buoyancy in the Narwhal. I also added a slot along the keel so that a penny can be used for ballast. The penny fits really tightly; however, the ballast is not necessary as the vessel still floats great without it. Furthermore, no support structure is needed for this print. The boat/toy is fun for for kids of all ages: great for the tub or pool.  Hope you enjoy and happy boating!

We asked our Facebook community what kind of planes do they want to see at an air show. They chose a seaplane, and here it is. Idea submitted by Aaron Z. to the GE Air Show at http://www.Facebook.com/GE

• Print the float plate (contains left and right half of both floats)
  • Print the left and right halves of the fuselage
  • Print the propeller (using support material)
  • Glue the float halves together - each float should have one solid
    piece and one with two holes
  • Drill two 1/8 holes in each fuselage half at a 45 degree angle
    (couldn't model them directly, OpenSCAD winding order bug...)
  • Glue the fuselage halves together
  • Use 4 pieces of filament about 3/4 inch long to attach the floats
    to the fuselage
  • Glue the prop on

comments.text: Hey guys, I ahev just printed this off on my UP! printer and it looks amazing!! however the right hand side of the fuselage is no where near the same as the left hand side the quality between them is poles apart the left hand side is finished to  good standard, where the right you can still see the support media very clearly as there is no top layer and both the main wing and the tailplane both have lot of support media and the quality is not as good as the other side.

Carro impreso para reemplazar el original, está para 2 hotends, pero dejo el archivo de sketchup para que se pueda adaptar. Está la versión lm8uu que es para los lineales y la versión para bujes de 8x12x16 (medida standard de BYC autolibricados). El soporte para los dos hotends es el standard pero también está para modificarse. Lo tengo montado pero todavía no está probado... parece estable pero el tiempo lo dirá. remixed_from.author: aaroncm
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 Bowden E3Dv6 Mount V2 - Optional Inductive Sensor Mount

title: Prusa i3 Bowden E3Dv6 Integrated Inductive Sensor Mount

description.text:
Remix of aaroncm's excellent E3Dv6 mount for Prusa i3. I've made some changes to make it more to my liking:
  • The inductive sensor is integrated in the mount for smaller form factor and higher stability.
  • Distances between parts are smaller. This makes the distance between the sensor and the nozzle smaller, and should give you a bigger print surface when using two hot ends.
  • More screw holes added for the hot end mount for added stability.
    • I also removed the sink for the screws attaching the mount to the X carriage, to make it easy to use washers on those screws. You'll need longer screws, probably M2x30. I have included both a single hot end version as well as a dual hot end version, as well as all sketchup files. I haven't tried the dual hot end version since I only have one.
    Also included is a sketchup file with all the separate parts so you can mix and match.

The Ikea Detolfs do not allow for extra shelves. I created these clips so that you can add more shelves. Each set of four allows for one extra shelf. Each pair is used to attach a horizontal rod to the vertical rods that come with the shelves. The full circles are to push through the metal rods you buy and cut (these will make the horizontal rods that the glass shelves sit on). They're meant to fit 1/4" rods and should have a bit of wiggle room, hence the extra cut. The half circles will snap onto the vertical rods already included in the Detolf. I used JB Kwik glue (that's the dark grey stuff coming out from the red clips in my picture) to hold them in place and was able to test them for 15 lbs (even though what I display is nowhere near that much). This design worked for me, but depending on the rods you buy and how they're made, the horizontal cylinders may need to be widened (so they don't crack) or made smaller (to fit the rod better). I found this measurement worked best for me, as I tried smaller which led to too many cracked pieces when I fed the rods through. I printed this with 70% infill, but less infill didn't affect the time, so I don't think there is much space inside for infill. I used 0.3 mm thickness. I didn't use rafts or supports. It's designed to not need them during the printing. For displaying my 6-7" action figures, I used the following measurements:
One rod placed between 4 1/4" and 4 1/2" above the top rod.
One rod placed between 5 1/4" and 5 1/2" below the top rod.
One rod placed between 5 1/4" and 5 1/2" above the bottom rod.
One rod placed between 4 1/4" and 4 1/2" below the bottom rod. This gave me five glass shelves (the four listed, plus I used the one in the middle that is part of the Detolf. The rest are unused) plus the bottom wood one and kept them all about 10" apart. I put the between measurements since each rod is 1/4", so that's the entire space it takes up. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9MINqkhN4iA

remixed_from.title: X52 HOTAS adapter plates for SVARTÅSEN Laptop stands

title: X-55 Rhino HOTAS adapter plates for SVARTÅSEN Laptop stands

description.text:
This is completely based off an excellent mounting plate design for the X-52s. I just adapted the mounting plates for the X-55 Rhino. All credit to http://www.thingiverse.com/GMBridge and see his original X-52 plate design here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1017785 Adapter plates & connectors to mount a X55 Rhino HOTAS (http://www.saitek.com/uk/prod/x55.html) to SVARTÅSEN Laptop stands (http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/40242177/). Might work for other HOTAS if they have the same mounting holes, or there are tinkercad links below to customize these. Includes the plates, some push pins to clip the plate to the laptop stand. I connected the X-55 to the mounting plate using eight 3" long 1/4 inch carriage bolts with wing nuts. You will need a large printing plate as these plates are 7"x9". I used a i3Mega-Prusa from 3DStuffmaker, PLA @ 0.4mm layers w/ 40% infill and 3 solid top and bottom layers for strength. Technically Since both the X-55 Throttle and Joystick have the same orientation and hole pattern on the X-55 Rhino it might be best to just print two of the Joystick Plates. This keeps the feet of the laptop stand in the same orientation for both modules, as there are guide slots and holes in the laptop stand and the plate that determine orientation. If you would like to modify this design, feel free to do so:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0vDojyYdg3s-x55-hotas-joystick-mounting-plate
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1eRPQBdHL8w-x55-hotas-throttle-mounting-plate
And the push-clip design bby GMBridge:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jsnwV3lncTR-hotas-push-clip
Print (as oriented) 1 each of the adapter plates (or 2 Joystick plates will work fine and keep stand orientation the same), 10 of the push clips (5 per plate) to mount plate to laptop stand.

title: Blinky Kitty
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
You always wanted a kitty with blinking LED, rainbow eyes, right? Now you can make as many as you want!
  • Blinky Kitty has a posable head, tail, arms, and flexible whiskers.
  • A tilt switch inside the tail activates Blinky Kitty's mesmerizing, rainbow, color-changing eyes.
  • Exposed battery terminals at the ears let you use Blinky Kitty as a 3V coin cell battery supply too.
  • You'll need Teknikio's Sparking Sense Set to complete this project!
Designed by Macakcat

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:
  • These two files should be printed with supports:
    1.) "CatHeadParts.stl"
    2.) "CatHeadMouth.stl"
  • Print the rest of the files without supports.
  • You'll need to print 2 arms!
  • For all files, 3 shells were used for additional strength.

Tools You'll Need
  • Wire Strippers
  • CA glue ("Super glue")
  • Small screwdriver of any type (Optional)
  • Hobby Knife
  • Wire Cutters
  • Small Pliers
  • Solder
  • Soldering Iron (Not pictured)
    • Some helpful tools The Electric Circuit Schematic Blinky Kitty is activated by a tilt switch hiding in the tail. You can shake, tilt, or pose Blinky Kitty's tail, to make Kitty's eyes glow and flash. Blinky Kitty's left and right eyes are wired in parallel and triggered by a tilt switch. Luckily for us, this circuit is simple and requires no current-limiting resistors. The forward voltage drop of the LED's and internal resistance of the 3V coin cell battery balance out to work perfectly. Please do not power Blinky Kitty with voltages higher than 3V as this will burn out the LED's! Teknikio Blinky Kitty Schematic Circuit Diagram Parts Required for your Blinky Kitty
  • Teknikio Sparking Sense Set (Kit includes a coin cell battery, Teknikio battery board, tilt switch, and 2 "rainbow" LED's needed for this project)
  • 6 pieces of 1" lengths of flexible filament for whiskers (1.75mm)
  • 2 pieces of 12" lengths of 22AWG, stranded wire
  • 1 piece of 1" length, 22AWG, stranded wire
  • You'll need to print each STL file supplied once, except for the arms because you'll need two of those.
    • Blinky Kitty Parts Assembly Tips
  • Adult supervision is required since we're working with a hot soldering iron and very strong CA glue.
  • Read each step carefully and refer to the indicated photos prior to assembling.
  • Be patient. Take your time. Half the fun is assembling your Blinky Kitty!
    • Step 1 - Prepping the Parts
  • Go ahead and print all the parts!
  • Be sure to use the print settings for the files as described earlier.
  • You'll find support material in the cat's head (part with the ears) and in Blinky Kitty's muzzle.
  • These should be carefully removed with pliers and any rough edges cleaned up with a hobby knife.
  • Be careful! It doesn't have to be perfect--just enough for the parts to fit nicely.
  • The inside of the muzzle is somewhat detailed. Be sure to check out the photo of the muzzle cleared of support material.
  • The rectangular opening in the underside of the muzzle is for ease of battery removal after assembly.
    • Blinky Kitty's head with support material removed Blinky Kitty's muzzle with support material removed Step 2 - Assembling Blinky Kitty's Eyes
  • Find the piece shaped like a sideways figure 8, these are Blinky Kitty's eye sockets.
  • There's no top or bottom to this piece, just a front (curved) and back (flat).
  • Drop or press the color-changing LED's in. They should sit flush with the flat side.
  • It makes wiring easier later on if you place these LED's in at 45 degree angles as shown in the below photo.
  • Be sure to place the longer, LED positive leads (anodes) on one side.
  • In the photo I have the positive leads towards the top, with the shorter negative leads (cathodes) towards the bottom.
    • Step 3 - Continuation of Eye assembly
  • Find the elliptical piece with two round holes in it. The elliptical piece has a rectangular notch in it. This notch faces the bottom of Blinky Kitty's face.
  • Examine the photo below. The photo is the bottom view of the complete eye assembly with the positive LED leads (the outer ones) facing the table and the negative LED leads closer to you (the middle ones). Note how the rectangular notch is on the side closer to the negative leads.
  • When you're satisfied with the LED positioning, place a small drop of CA glue on the sideways figure 8, and carefully position the elliptical piece onto it, in the correct orientation, centering it with the LED's.
    • View of the eye assembly from the underside Step 4 - Wiring the LED's in parallel
  • Carefully bend the four LED leads--the positive to positive, and the negative to negative.
  • Solder these together in parallel.
    • Soldering the LED leads in parallel Step 5 - Adding the 1" wire
  • Your 1" wire will go from the positive battery terminal to the positive anodes of the LED eyes.
  • As in the second photo below, solder the other end of the wire to the positive battery terminal.
    • Wire attached to LED positive anodes Wire end attached to positive battery terminal Step 6 - Adding the 12" wires and Assembling Blinky Kitty's face
  • In the next photo, I've soldered the red 12" wire to the negative terminals (cathodes) of the LED's, and I've soldered the black 12" wire to the negative battery terminal.
  • It's important that these wires are soldered in place as shown since there isn't much space for them in Blinky Kitty's little head.
  • Leave the wires long for now!
  • In the second picture below, I test fit Blinky Kitty's muzzle to the board, then glued it in place along with the eye assembly.
  • Be sure the route the wires to come out of lower portion of the battery board as shown!
    • 12 Blinky Kitty's head fitted and glued with the wires routed as shown Step 7 - Assembling the back of Blinky Kitty's head
  • Thread the 12" wire leads through the hole in Blinky Kitty's neck as shown below.
  • As in the second photo below, place 4 small drops of glue and carefully line the back of the head up with the front as you glue them together.
  • The third photo below shows you how everything should line up.
    • Thread the wires in through the hole in the neck Apply some glue as shown Carefully assemble and it should look like this! Blinky Kitty is taking form! Step 8 - Adding whiskers to Blinky Kitty
  • Next, using the six 1" flexible filament pieces you've prepared, glue them into the dimples in Blinky Kitty's muzzle.
  • Trim them down to size as you like.
  • You don't have to use flexible filament for the whiskers but I think it works better.
    • Blinky Kitty's head is done! Step 9 - Giving Blinky Kitty some arms!
  • Add a drop of glue to the pegs on the end of the arms and carefully glue them into Blink Kitty's arm ball joints.
  • Give the glue some time to set and wiggle the arms a little bit.
  • The ball joints should break free and Blinky Kitty can finally wave "Hello!"
    • Blinky Kitty's arms attached Step 10 - Routing the wires
  • Thread the long wires from the head through the ball joint at the top of Blinky Kitty's body.
  • There may be some additional filament blockage in this hole--that's normal.
  • If you need to, use a small screwdriver and gently press it into the hole. This will clear some space for the wires to fit through.
  • I sent the wires all the way down through big hole at the bottom of Blinky Kitty's body to make Step 11 easier.
    • Routing the wires Step 11 - Routing the wires continued
  • Next thread the wires back up and through the ball joint for Blinky Kitty's tail.
  • Blinky Kitty should now look as in the photo below.
  • Add a drop of glue to Blinky Kitty's neck and push it into the ball joint at the top.
  • Give the glue some time to adhere and twist Blinky Kitty's head a few times to break the ball joint free.
    • Wire routing completed Step 12 - Adjusting the wire length in the tail
  • In this step, I've placed the wires into one half of the tail assembly. This is to help you get the wires cut to an appropriate length.
  • One end of the tail has a peg that goes into the ball joint. The other end has an enlarged opening for the tail tip and tilt switch to fit in.
    • Getting ready to trim the wires for the tilt switch... Step 13 - Adjusting the wire length in the tail continued
  • Trim the red and black wires about 2 to 3mm from the end of the tail section.
  • These need to be short so we don't have too much wire slack since there's limited space.
    • Cut the wires at this position... Step 14 - Preparing the wires for the Tilt Switch
  • Carefully strip the very ends of the wire and tin them.
    • Wires stripped and tinned... Step 15 - Assembling the tail tip and adding the Tilt Switch
  • Find your tail tip and tilt switch
  • Gently push the tilt switch into the tail tip. This is a somewhat tight fit, but the switch needs to go in as far as you can push it.
  • I used some pliers to help me hold the switch as I pushed it in.
  • The second photo below shows how far the leads will stick out once the switch is all the way in.
    • Tail tip and Tilt Switch before assembly Tilt Switch pushed into the tail tip Step 16 - Trimming the Tilt Switch leads
  • Using wire cutters, trim the leads for the tilt switch shorter. They should stick out by 1 to 2mm.
    • Step 17 - Soldering the Tilt Switch to Blinky Kitty
  • Carefully solder the tilt switch to the ends of Blinky Kitty's tail wires you prepared earlier.
    • Step 18 - Assembling Blinky Kitty's tail
  • Starting with one of the tail halves, guide the wires into place with the tail fitted onto the end.
  • At this point you can add a drop of glue to the tail half and tail tip junction to help holds things in place.
    • Wire fitment and attaching the tail tip to the first tail half Step 19 - Assembling Blinky Kitty's tail continued
  • Next, add a few drops of glue along the inside of the first tail half, then very carefully position the second tail half over it and stick them in place.
  • Your Blinky Kitty should look like the photo below.
  • Once that's all done, you can add a small drop of glue to the base of the tail and insert it into Blinky Kitty's rear ball joint.
  • Give the glue a short time to adhere, then twist the tail a few times to break the ball joint free.
    • Finishing up Blinky Kitty's tail Step 20 - You're all done!
  • At this point Blinky Kitty should be all assembled!
  • Place the 3V coin cell battery into Blinky Kitty's head (positive towards the front of Blinky's face), wiggle the tail and watch your kitty's eyes light up!
    • Hiiii!

This is a remake of my original card holder, I came up with this when I visited my grandfather who was having issues holding cards when we would play this was due to his age but it now made it very hard for him to play card games that he enjoyed with me. So I made the first card holder and sent it to him he enjoyed it greatly as the slots make it super easy to put cards it and orginise them, but the large size makes it hard to tip over. With all the rows there was plenty of space for when we played Uno those of you who have played will know how you can get 30+ cards, the only down side is if you looked over it was rather easy to see the cards, that problem has been addressed in this one as I put large sides on it to prevent wandering eyes. Unfortunately I cannot make another one of these at college (or at least not yet) so I have kept all dimensions the same as the old one so use it as a reference for size.  If you see any problems with it or have a suggestion let me know I will be making improvements.

description.text: This is a figure of my Dungeons and Dragons character, Mhu. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/428Uzp4U9YW

Really needed to clean up my electronics so needed a housing. Searched on thingiverse, but only found RAMPS 1.2 housings.
Inspired by aMess and araspitfires housing I made this one.

I found the slots for the front openings to be a bit hard to cut out.
It's a good idea to make the supports from less material so you can cut them out easier. I just fitted the RAMPS in the enclosure and it is a very snug fit, as you can see on the photos.
I had to grind some material of the inside to make some more room for the front power connector on the Arduino.
I also had to grind some material of the outside to clip-fit the external power connector.
Some more room for the board would be better too, say 3mm on each side. I've posted the files for version 2.
Changes:
  • 3mm more inside space on all sides
  • Removed all supports (also for the fan-opening)
  • Added some space for the Arduino power connector
  • The lid also has 1mm space around the inserts (no push fit)
  • The Arduino mounts are a bit more solid now
  • Made the opening for the front power connector bigger

description.text: This is a mod of a lanlan brand master skewb. In order to make this you will need to get one of them. You will also need some superglue to attach the pieces. If oriented correctly none of the pieces should need supports. If you would like professionally cut stickers for it and don't have access to a plotter/cutter or enough colors, Oliver from Oliver's stickers is making them available for sale here. http://oliverstickers.com/floyd-s-fluorite.html A video of the final puzzle without a complete set of stickers is available here. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EB5bhXs1DUw Please keep in mind prior to making this that it isn't a speed cube. Care must be taken to ensure proper alignment prior to turning or a piece could pop out. This however will be less likely if the base puzzle is under tight tensions.

comments.text:
Hey that is a real beauty of a puzzle.
I also like the Idea of using a mass-Produced puzzle as the Core, for better turning quality.

comments.author: Stangelnat

comments.text: I just used PLA at the default settings for .2mm resolution for my printer.You shouldn't need anything special. The top center piece does snap onto the bottom center part. Just be careful when you do it or you could potentially break the bottom part. I wiggled them slowly and carefully together. Some force will most likely be required though. After they are together they should turn relatively easy and it breaking shouldn't really be an issue unless you try to take it back apart for some reason.

Finished sourcing the parts and built you printer, now what? Stuff everything on a box of course!

Stay Tuned for the lid!

description.text: This is a rock wall hold that is submitted for the Open Source 3-D printing class at Michigan Tech. Submitted by Tyler Jubenville

This is a duct for an 80mm fan.  
This made the print worse than not using the duct, but better than a 60mm fan. I would suggest no duct.

Video of zoetrope in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_E09L5mKf18 These are 3D models of working 3D zoetrope. There are 10 poses of walking elephant.
In this version I used stepper motor and LED strobe light controlled by arduino. I'm planning to improve design in the future. The best effect can be observed in the dark, ambient light will add motion smudges. The elephants print better upside down, they need to be resized to scale of 0.3 (sorry, forgot to do that before exporting to STL). The elephants then need to be glued to the inserts using glue gun and then inserted into the disk. The trick is to align the animals in the same order, 01 to 10. If some poses don't align, a head gun can be used to melt the glue and re-adjust pose correspondingly. The purpose of inserts is to be able to use different animations on the same rig. However you can glue the elephants to the disk, in this case no need to print the inserts. More details on http://www.cthackerspace.com/lets-not-ignore-the-elephant-in-the-room/

description.text: The Gear I created with cliffords Gear Script (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:829) and the Rack I created using my own quick and dirty experimental Rack Script (https://whatever.metalab.at/user/wizard23/RackGenerator) which takes a closed loop (like a gear or a star, or a heart) and creates the fitting rack for rolling this object.

Cut it out and marvel at the beauty of rolling curves or use it for some playful mechanical contraption you devise.
This rack was calculated with zero slack. After I lasercut it - which makes the cutted thing a tiny fraction smaller because the laser has some width) it rolled very smoothly. If you use this with a CNC you might want to add some slack.

author: swallen

title: Rostock MAX v2 - Spool Support Arm - Mod RL 2x 608

description.text:
Spool Holder for Rostock MAX v2
I've seen a lot of designs out there, but I couldn't find anything that was perfect for me, so I designed this one.  It has three spacers included to align the center of the Spool of Filament perfectly over the exit hole in the top of a Rostock MAX v2 using SeeMeCNC Filaments.  Other spools should work just the same as they pretty much all use the same spool dimensions...  Usually.

The .STL's are VERY highly detailed as I don't like seeing poorly executed .STL exporting! Items needed:
  • 608-ZZ or 608-2Z Bearings x4
  • M8 x 1.25 x 190mm Threaded Rod x1
  • M8 x 1.25 Nylon-Insert Locknut x1
  • M8 Washer x1
    • The M8 x 1.25 x 190mm Threaded Rod should be a tight push fit into the "Spool Support Arm - Mod RL 2x 608". If not, you can use a glue or bonding agent to secure it. For 0.5kg spools use the "10.5mm Spacer"
    For 1.0kg spools use the "18.7mm Spacer"
    For 1.0lbs Taulman spools use the "1.0mm Spacer" Press fit the "M8 Knob - RL 2x 608" onto the M8 x 1.25 Nylon-Insert Locknut. Don't forget the M8 Washer before installing the "M8 Knob - RL 2x 608". Tighten the "M8 Knob - RL 2x 608" up against the M8 Washer until there is no play. Do not over tighten as you want just enough to set the preload in the 608 Bearings. See Photorealistic Renderings for more details. Print using either ABS or PLA. Infill: 50% to 100%
    Supports: Where needed. Enjoy!

comments.text: Printed mine at 25% infil withi Carbon Fiber PLA. turned out well the M8 threaded scree went in just fine one the 10mm washer and the end hook. I had some serious issues with nylon m8 nut being too difficult. So I used a regular m8 nut and that seems to be working well. the spool cones printed well, tho I had some serious fit issues with the bearings. only managed to get one in on each cone. Still seems to be working better than the stock spool holder. I can see what some people mean when they say the design is a bit of extra work with the washers and the extra parts to remove when changing filament. It isnt as easy as just slinging on a new spool. I have extra bearings (since I only used two the first time) and some extra threaded rod (since Ace only sells it in 3 foot chucks). So i am going to print another spool holder. I can queue up another spool when im ready and just pop off the old spool + holder making the exchange less cumbersome.
comments.author: T3CHKOMMIE

comments.text: Make sure your printer is calibrated properly (arm length size) for the part(s) to be printed at the correct scale/size.  If so, the bearings should be a slight press fit, by hand.  The correct tolerances were put into the model to accommodate the bearings and other hardware.

author: gregrjohnson

description.text:
Shenzhou 8 spacecraft of China, roughly in 1:100 scale (92.5mm long)
by Chin, Chien Ting (ctchin) This model is well (but not fully) parametrized, it is possible to customize various dimensions and to import various modules (e.g. the solar array at customizable folding angle). No surface details have been added (yet), the ends are bare. Propulsion at the Service Module and docking/airlock at the Orbital Module would be desirable. If you would add to this model (with OpenSCAD) please let me know! Reference image and dimensions from
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shenzhou_(spacecraft) When importing this model, the reference point (origin) is located at the end of the Service Module, for the purpose of docking to another craft or space station. For the purpose of 3D printing, re-orient this model to the requirement of the printer (see, e.g. line 15). For a practical 3D printed model, it is advised to modify the Solar array connector solarcon(lc,hc) or even to eliminate it.

description.text: This is designed with Sketchup as a beefed up replacement part for a Trifecta arm which had snapped in a spectacular crash. No replacement arm was available besides buying a new complete kit. In PLA at 100% fill, it weighs approx. 16g, with the original being 15.5g. The motor mounting holes have to be custom drilled to fit your use. Due to the limitation of the printing grain, the attachment region for the swiveling landing gear is extremely weak. That portion for my prints easily and repeatedly snapped off. Please use at your discretion. The rev. 2 designation was simply my attempt to improve on this without success. However, I utilize heli skids for landing gear, so this did not effect my usage.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm or close

Infill:

100%

Notes: These were simply my choices which worked well for me without much of an impact on weight when comparing with the original. Print upside down. Support is needed because of the indentations present on the swiveling end of the arm (end that attaches to the Trifecta body). Hole for the pin for attaching swiveling landing leg may need be enlarged slightly. Once again, that region is a little weak from the inherent grain of the print.

title: MakerGear M2 OctoPi and LCD Control Box for Pi B+

description.text: This is a MakerGear M2 OctoPi control box and LCD cradle with mounting holes for Raspberry PI B+ running OctoPi. It will only work the the Raspberry Pi B+ due to the mounting holes. I was getting a bit frustrated with the stock Geetech LCD flopping about, and also wanted a solid mount for my Raspberry Pi B+. This provides both, and bolts to the right side of the M2 using the existing mounting screws (without the washers). The assembly pictures are pretty self explanatory. Assembly with Cyanoacrylate, except you'll probably want to leave the LCD box floating so it can be removed to access the Pi. You may need to drill a bit for the mounting screw holes to get a good fit. You can use a couple of pieces of 1.75mm clear filament cut at 45 degree angle and press fit into holes leading to Pi LEDs. If these overlap the LEDs, they act nicely as light pipes to see those LEDs on the front (power and activity).

i built the first doodle clock http://hackaday.com/2012/03/14/robotic-doodle-clock/ 3 years ago as a joke. But to watch the clock work was so mesmerizing that i wanted it to be a practical desk clock. The biggest problem with the first clock was the drying up of the markers after just 30 minutes of working. So the solution to that i found was the magnetic writing boards http://www.walmart.com/ip/Fisher-Price-Doodle-Pro-Basic-Purple/26012794 made for children. I used 2mm cylindrical magnets inside a solenoid to write and erase the text. Next i replaced the servos with small geared steppers to make the clock very silent and smoother. And finally all parts were designed and 3d printed . I also got the final pcb manufactured . http://hackaday.com/2015/10/06/robot-clock-writes-time-over-and-over-and-over/ https://youtu.be/MmIP156JIxg

description.text: Customizable Lipo battery sleeve Need a sleeve for your Lipo but just can't find a good model that matches and don't want to take the time to whip up one of your own? Use the customizer to create a battery sleeve that fits just right. The sleeve has attachment holes, affordance settings, and optional hold-downs that can be filed down to create a tight fit. You may damage your Lipo if the fit is too tight, so take care not to force the battery in but rather to file down the holder until the battery can slide in easily. Thanks to adafruit for the original design.

A remix of the XY ends designed for the Eustathios and Herculien reprap printers. Please note this is a work in progress and has not been tested extensively. Perceived benefits include: 1) The bearings have more freedom (more tolerant of misalignment). Smoother motion before running break in routine. 2) Uses this bearing from Robotdigg (http://www.robotdigg.com/product/451/Selfgraphite+10*14*30mm+Linear+Bearing) and the design could be adapted for Igus or Simplicity bearings. 3) Bearings are easy to remove and replace. 4) Split rod clamp simplifies assembly because you can drop the cross bars in place after the outer rods are inserted.

This base was designed to be fitted on my Globe Bouquet Vase so that it can be placed on a pillar/pole in the garden... https://www.shapeways.com/shops/palmigadesigns
http://www.sculpteo.com/en/u/palmiga-innovation/s/palmiga-innovation/ I designed my Globe Bouquet Vase as a miniature protest against all the 3D printed vases that focuses on the actual vase ;) It´s fun and nice to see the creativity designing the most complex 3D printed vase but isn't the flowers the main attraction and also the most beautiful? No 3D print can come close to that beauty right? My vase was designed to blend in... to showcase the flowers by helping to form a Globe Bouquet.
Don´t get me wrong... I of course still wanted the design to be somewhat appealing on its own and I do think the end result is a good compromise. Obviously it´s designed to be printed without support and it´s possible to scale down a bit to fit lots of printers (174 mm x 179 mm x 159 mm at 100%). In my pictures and movies it´s printed at 80% with 0.2mm layers and a 0.7mm nozzle.
Combined with the base part and a pillar it´s a good start creating a parkway framed with elevated Globe Bouquets... (base printed at 70% in the picture) The outer holes together with the holes in the inner geometry creates endless combinations when arranging the flowers. If one does not like the flower aspect I guess it would double great at Comic Con as the top of a Wizard Staff or Alien Weaponry perhaps? I challenge everyone to make a creative base for the Globe Bouquet Vase so that it can morph into something completely new ;) No rules... and the price is fame, glory and hopefully pride :- ) The lowest 2mm of the vase is available here as a STEP-file so that you easily can design your own unique base... The vase it self is available as a free download here: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/palmiga-globe-bouquet-vase-13379
but is also part of the "Support free Vase & Planter Design competition" thus it´s now available for only $9.99 during the competition (compared to the standard $39) Enjoy!
KR Thomas Please also check out my unuiqe UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament. Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this: This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design: •The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc. http://rubber3dprinting.com/

author: retam3

description.text: This remix features improved performance on the original design (thing:30284) by Landru. Thing 30284 is an awesome design with a pretty clever approach to printing orientation for optimal durability, but unfortunately it fails to provide sufficient lift for my drone. Thus, this remix. Note: These blades were designed to fit Sky Viper quadcopters such as v950hd. Once I move on to something more "grown up" (possibly print the Crossfire 2 by MikeyB, thing:234867), I'll upload the revised designs. It's preferred that after 3D-printing is complete the blades hang out in an acetone vapor bath for about 30 minutes (40 max), followed by a 3-4 hour cure period. This process fuses the layers which makes them a little more durable and improves aerodynamics. And as a bonus feature it gives them a nice glossy finish. After the printing and finishing is done with the above mentioned parameters, the props turn out to be 14cm in diameter and weigh 2.54 grams (0.5 grams heavier than the stock props). It took me about 2 hours to print a set of four blades. While not as good as the stock blades, with additional tweaking they should perform almost as good. The video of them in action is also here: https://youtu.be/MT1IOt7kbHA Have fun, and always remember to exercise extreme caution when operating unmanned areal vehicles near humans, pets, and other people's private property. Thanks!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.17mm

Infill:

0.3

Notes: Printing the attached STL file will get you a pair of "A" blades. To get a set of the "B" blades I simply set my object's Y-axis scale from "1" to a "-1" before slicing it. Also, don't worry about the support material, as I've already included it in the STL's mesh. You can set your slicer to whatever settings you prefer, however, I've had most success printing it in ABS plastic from a 0.40mm nozzle at 0.17mm layer height, 30% infill, and a 2-layer shell. My printer's extruder and hotbed temperatures were set at 215 and 112 degrees Celsius. I used a Solidoodle 3 device and its default software Repetier Host.

title: F-22 Raptor Jet with display stand, removable missiles

description.text: Also available in our Etsy! http://etsy.me/12W7uce F22 Raptor model by Thingiverse user IIIWhiteBoyIII, simplified for easy printing and adapted with pinpeg snap components. Everything is snap-together, and the missiles house a hidden compartment. The missile fins can rotate and pop off -- and a small hole in the center can hold a tiny (really fortune cookie size) piece of paper. This was a custom commission we did last month, to build a set of 70 planes with 140 missiles -- in under 7 days. You can read about the details on our blog: http://carrythewhat.com/blog/?p=191

For every plane you print, print 1 base, 1 stand, 2 missile tops and 2 missile bottoms, and 2 pins.  
The missile pieces will have to be printed with heavy infill, or they'll be  delicate and they might break when putting together. Everything is designed to be printed without support.  
After that - everything is snap together!

remixed_from.author: GregFrost
remixed_from.title: Parametric Involute  Bevel and Spur Gears

title: Lens Gear for Follow Focus - Seamless Friction Fit for Lenses 50-100mm diameter and beyond!

description.text: Convert your non-geared camera lenses to work with follow focus gearing. 50-100mm diameter in 0.5mm steps. OpenSCAD script to generate your own! There are some great lens gear projects on Thingiverse, and plenty of inventive commercially available lens gears. Many of them require bolts, zip ties or other hardware though, which gets in the way of everything and also prevents full 360º rotation, which is super useful for many stills lenses which don't have hard focus stops. But wait! Having a 3D printer means you can print custom things exactly the right size for your stuff, as long as someone has taken the time to design a right-sized model. I've uploaded lens gears from 50-100mm diameter in 0.5mm steps, and included the SCAD script if you need something tiny/huge/weird/awesome. Thanks to help from sveltema it is also enabled in Customiser, so you can generate a gear between 3-200mm internal diameter, and up to 60mm thick!

Measure the diameter of the focus ring on your lens. I use digital callipers for maximum accuracy, but a ruler, a piece of string, and some math can also get you in the ballpark. Example: Nikkor 50mm F1.2 focus ring diameter = ~68.3mm Multiply by shrinkage factor if needed. Different materials shrink when cooled. ABS by 2-5%, PLA by less. If you print something precisely sized to your focus ring it probably won't fit. If you don't want to do SCIENCE just add 0.5-1mm for your first test print. Example: 68.3 x 1.02 = 69.666mm, rounded = 69.5mm. Download lensgear_69.5mm_94t.stl for printing. Optional: Calculate number of teeth required & choose gear thickness.
If you'd like to use Customizer you can choose arbitrary teeth numbers until the gear looks about right, or if you'd like gears with a specific outer diameter (perhaps you'd like a matching set with common diameters for all your different lenses?) you can use a calculator to figure out how many teeth you need. Lens gears are sized "Mod 0.8". Thickness is the measurement of the band contacting your focus ring. Perhaps you need an extra thick gear because the focus ring on your cool antique lens moves in and out? Example: 80mm outer diameter = 98 teeth. 15mm thickness looks super cool. Make some test prints. When finding the right size I generally stop my test prints at around 20% completion, which is enough to test for fit without wasting time and filament. If you stop too soon you'll have to deal with the oversized bottom layer of squished filament, so let the print go for a couple of mm high so you can test the actual fit on your lens. If it doesn't fit, there are plenty of other sizes to try! Example: 69.5mm, won't go on! 70.5mm, doesn't grip. 70mm = perfect. Sand and file your perfectly sized gear. I generally remove the squashed bottom layer, which adds a little lip that prevents a correctly sized gear from sliding all the way on to my focus ring. Scraping with the blade of a pair of scissors is generally enough to get rid of this. Apply to lens. If it's the right size you'll require some patience to gradually work the gear on to your focus ring. Brute force shouldn't be necessary though. If you think you might need a mallet, try going up 0.5mm in diameter.

description.header: What about weird shaped lenses with protruding greebles?
description.text:
If your lens has too much in the way of AF/MF selector switches, knobs or protrusions, you might have trouble getting a correctly-sized gear to fit slide over them. To fix this I've been using a two-piece solution:
  • Gear internal diameter is sized to fit over the obstacle.
  • Spacer printed as a split cylinder, allowing a tight friction fit.
    • It's a couple of extra steps, but it works just as well as a one-piece gear if you get the diameters correct. I've been making the spacers in Tinkercad, but if there's enough interest I'll whip up a quick script that'll allow people to generate custom spacers as well.

I've used gears just like these for over a year. They work beautifully, and my ABS ones are yet to show any significant wear. They also look much more professional than having gears zip-tied or bolted to your lenses.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: I generally use 2 shells and keep the gear profile relatively thin, so infill doesn't really get used. If for some reason you need thick gears that need to stand up to lots of punishment from heavy lenses or vicious focus pullers you may want to increase the shells and infill.

Due to differences in material shrinkage (ABS shrinks more than PLA, for instance) you can't really say "a 70mm diameter gear will fit all Nikkor 50mm F1.2 lenses." So I've been using Inkscape/Tinkercad to manually design gear models whose diameters were stepped by 0.5mm increments until I found sizes which perfectly friction-fit my different lenses. All the while thinking "a complete set of these covering a wide range of sizes would be super useful for the filmmaking community". Eventually I found GregFrost's Parametric Involute Bevel and Spur Gears script, and taught myself enough OpenSCAD to modify it to just produce gears with the correct tooth pitch for standard follow focus systems.
I was manually sanding off the sharp edges of my gears, so I also modified the design to bevel off those pointy teeth that snag on your camera bag/delicate human flesh.

I've been working in various nerdy aspects of film/video/live visuals production for a decade. Recently I've decided to go solo to work on more of the projects that I believe will help filmmakers and creative video people make better stuff. This is the first thing I'm releasing. If it helps you complete an awesome shoot, streamlines your rig, or saves you a bunch of cash, maybe you'd like to give me some gold coins? Or otherwise support the creation of future nerdy filmmaking tools? If so, please get in touch.

2016-01-05 - Updated instructions for Customizer / Diameter Calculation jlevie01's comment made me realise that I'd written the instructions before Customizer was enabled, so they assumed you're just using one of my pre-made STL files. Added a couple of extra steps for those generating custom lens diameters/thicknesses. 2015-11-19 - Customiser enabled. Code on Github. Customiser enabled thanks to assistance from sveltema
Project/OpenSCAD added to Github. 2015-11-18 - Posted on Hackaday! 3D Printed Lens Gears for Pro Grade Focus Pulling. Thanks Hackaday.

description.text: This is a replacement kog for the game KogWorks. We lost a kog so I designed a printable one. Now I just need to colour match the filament...

The workflow for this was a bit ridiculous.
  • I tried scanning and photographing the kog but shadows kept getting in the way of a clear outline.
  • I was able to trace one tooth and part of the central hole in Gimp. I saved this part out.
  • I used GeoGebra to find the center of the hole and copy-rotate the tooth around.
  • I traced the image with Inkscape and saved out the DXF.
  • Finally used OpenSCAD to extrude the DXF.
